answer_html: where the above sum ranges over all integers \(\displaystyle 1 \leq k \leq n\) with \(\displaystyle \gcd(k,n) = 1\)?
answer_latex:
where the above sum ranges over all integers
$\displaystyle 1 \leq k \leq n$ with $\displaystyle \gcd(k,n) = 1$?
hints_html: If m and n differ, then there is a largest prime which they differ. Starting with that, argue using a descent argument.
hints_latex:
If \emph{m} and \emph{n} differ, then there is a largest prime which
they differ. Starting with that, argue using a descent argument.
hints_raw: If ''m'' and ''n'' differ, then there is a largest prime which they differ. Starting with that, argue using a descent argument.
sols_html:
The claim is clearly true of one of m or n equals 1. Thus we suppose that both are strictly greater than 1.

In this case, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic tells us that we may write

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle m = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle n = \prod_{j=1}^{\ell}q_{j}^{\beta_{j}}\end{aligned}\]

where each of the exponents is a positive integer at least 1. The left hand side of the equation in question thus reduces to

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle m\phi(m) = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\left(\prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)\right) = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{2\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)\end{aligned}\]

and in total as we are given that \(\displaystyle m\phi(m) = n\phi(n)\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{2\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1) = \prod_{j=1}^{\ell}q_{j}^{2\beta_{j}-1}(q_{j}-1)\end{aligned}\]

Now, suppose that m and n are distinct. Let \(\displaystyle p_{0}\) be the largest prime where they differ and without loss of generality, suppose that \(\displaystyle p_{0}^{\alpha_{0}} \parallel m\) but \(\displaystyle p_{0}^{\alpha_{0}} \nmid n\). Then we know that we must have that \(\displaystyle p_{0} \mid (q_{j_{0}}-1)\) for some \(\displaystyle j_{0}\). Thus \(\displaystyle q_{j_{0}} > p_{0}\).

However, \(\displaystyle p_{0}\) was chosen to be the largest such prime where m and n differ to any power. So \(\displaystyle q_{j_{0}}^{\beta_{j_{0}}} = p_{i_{0}}^{\alpha_{i_{0}}}\) for some \(\displaystyle i_{0}\) and thus \(\displaystyle (q_{j_{0}}-1) = (p_{i_{0}}-1)\). Thus, we may cancel out these terms and repeat this argument to find another index \(\displaystyle j_{0}\) and since there are only finitely many of these terms, we must eventually reach a contradiction.

Hence m and n have all the same prime factors to the same powers and thus are equal.

Food for thought: Is there an easier proof of this using the fact that

\(\displaystyle n\phi(n) =2 \sum k\)

where the above sum ranges over all integers \(\displaystyle 1 \leq k \leq n\) with \(\displaystyle \gcd(k,n) = 1\)?
sols_latex:
The claim is clearly true of one of \emph{m} or \emph{n} equals 1. Thus
we suppose that both are strictly greater than 1.

In this case, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic tells us that we may
write

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle m = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}
\end{align*}

and

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle n = \prod_{j=1}^{\ell}q_{j}^{\beta_{j}}
\end{align*}

where each of the exponents is a positive integer at least 1. The left
hand side of the equation in question thus reduces to

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle m\phi(m) = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\left(\prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)\right) = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{2\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)
\end{align*}

and in total as we are given that $\displaystyle m\phi(m) = n\phi(n)$,
we have

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{2\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1) = \prod_{j=1}^{\ell}q_{j}^{2\beta_{j}-1}(q_{j}-1)
\end{align*}

Now, suppose that \emph{m} and \emph{n} are distinct. Let
$\displaystyle p_{0}$ be the largest prime where they differ and without
loss of generality, suppose that
$\displaystyle p_{0}^{\alpha_{0}} \parallel m$ but
$\displaystyle p_{0}^{\alpha_{0}} \nmid n$. Then we know that we must
have that $\displaystyle p_{0} \mid (q_{j_{0}}-1)$ for some
$\displaystyle j_{0}$. Thus $\displaystyle q_{j_{0}} > p_{0}$.

However, $\displaystyle p_{0}$ was chosen to be the largest such prime
where \emph{m} and \emph{n} differ to any power. So
$\displaystyle q_{j_{0}}^{\beta_{j_{0}}} = p_{i_{0}}^{\alpha_{i_{0}}}$
for some $\displaystyle i_{0}$ and thus
$\displaystyle (q_{j_{0}}-1) = (p_{i_{0}}-1)$. Thus, we may cancel out
these terms and repeat this argument to find another index
$\displaystyle j_{0}$ and since there are only finitely many of these
terms, we must eventually reach a contradiction.

Hence \emph{m} and \emph{n} have all the same prime factors to the same
powers and thus are equal.

\textbf{Food for thought}: Is there an easier proof of this using the
fact that

$\displaystyle n\phi(n) =2 \sum k$

where the above sum ranges over all integers
$\displaystyle 1 \leq k \leq n$ with $\displaystyle \gcd(k,n) = 1$?
sols_raw:
The claim is clearly true of one of ''m'' or ''n'' equals 1. Thus we suppose that both are strictly greater than 1.

In this case, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic tells us that we may write

:<math> \displaystyle m = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}</math>

and

:<math> \displaystyle n = \prod_{j=1}^{\ell}q_{j}^{\beta_{j}}</math>

<!--- :<math> \displaystyle n = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\beta_{i}}</math> --->
<!--- where above, we allow for convenience that one of <math> \displaystyle \alpha_{i}</math> or <math> \displaystyle \beta_{i}</math> to be zero for each ''i'' but never both. --->
where each of the exponents is a positive integer at least 1. The left hand side of the equation in question thus reduces to

:<math> \displaystyle m\phi(m) = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\left(\prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)\right) = \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{2\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)</math>

and in total as we are given that <math> \displaystyle m\phi(m) = n\phi(n)</math>, we have

:<math> \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}^{2\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1) = \prod_{j=1}^{\ell}q_{j}^{2\beta_{j}-1}(q_{j}-1)</math>

Now, suppose that ''m'' and ''n'' are distinct. Let <math> \displaystyle p_{0}</math> be the largest prime where they differ and without loss of generality, suppose that <math> \displaystyle p_{0}^{\alpha_{0}} \parallel m</math> but <math> \displaystyle p_{0}^{\alpha_{0}} \nmid n</math>. Then we know that we must have that <math> \displaystyle p_{0} \mid (q_{j_{0}}-1)</math> for some <math> \displaystyle j_{0}</math>. Thus <math> \displaystyle q_{j_{0}} > p_{0}</math>.

However, <math> \displaystyle p_{0}</math> was chosen to be the largest such prime where ''m'' and ''n'' differ to any power. So <math> \displaystyle q_{j_{0}}^{\beta_{j_{0}}} = p_{i_{0}}^{\alpha_{i_{0}}}</math> for some <math> \displaystyle i_{0} </math> and thus <math> \displaystyle (q_{j_{0}}-1) = (p_{i_{0}}-1)</math>. Thus, we may cancel out these terms and repeat this argument to find another index <math> \displaystyle j_{0}</math> and since there are only finitely many of these terms, we must eventually reach a contradiction.

Hence ''m'' and ''n'' have all the same prime factors to the same powers and thus are equal.

'''Food for thought''': Is there an easier proof of this using the fact that 

<math> \displaystyle n\phi(n) =2 \sum k</math>

where the above sum ranges over all integers <math> \displaystyle 1 \leq k \leq n</math> with <math> \displaystyle \gcd(k,n) = 1</math>?
statement_html: Let \(\displaystyle m,n \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(\displaystyle m\phi(m) = n\phi(n)\). Prove that \(\displaystyle m=n\)
statement_latex:
Let $\displaystyle m,n \in \mathbb{N}$ such that
$\displaystyle m\phi(m) = n\phi(n)$. Prove that $\displaystyle m=n$
statement_raw: Let <math> \displaystyle m,n \in \mathbb{N}</math> such that <math> \displaystyle m\phi(m) = n\phi(n)</math>. Prove that <math> \displaystyle m=n</math>
